distribution.text: Copyright Â© Red Hat, Inc. All rights reserved.

notes.text:
An update for kpatch-patch is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.0 Extended Update Support.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
This is a kernel live patch module which is automatically loaded by the RPM post-install script to modify the code of a running kernel.

Security Fix(es):

* kernel: KVM: cmpxchg_gpte can write to pfns outside the userspace region (CVE-2022-1158)

* kernel: openvswitch: integer underflow leads to out-of-bounds write in reserve_sfa_size() (CVE-2022-2639)

* kernel: watch queue race condition can lead to privilege escalation (CVE-2022-2959)

* kernel: nfsd buffer overflow by RPC message over TCP with garbage data (CVE-2022-43945)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: A flaw was found in KVM. When updating a guest's page table entry, vm_pgoff was improperly used as the offset to get the page's pfn. As vaddr and vm_pgoff are controllable by user-mode processes, this flaw allows unprivileged local users on the host to write outside the userspace region and potentially corrupt the kernel, resulting in a denial of service condition.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: KVM: cmpxchg_gpte can write to pfns outside the userspace region
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258
Red Hat has investigated whether a possible mitigation exists for this issue, and has not been able to identify a practical example. Please update the affected package as soon as possible.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: KVM: cmpxchg_gpte can write to pfns outside the userspace region

notes.text: An integer coercion error was found in the openvswitch kernel module. Given a sufficiently large number of actions, while copying and reserving memory for a new action of a new flow, the reserve_sfa_size() function does not return -EMSGSIZE as expected, potentially leading to an out-of-bounds write access. This flaw allows a local user to crash or potentially escalate their privileges on the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: openvswitch: integer underflow leads to out-of-bounds write in reserve_sfa_size()
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The `openvswitch` is not supported out of the Layered Products subscriptions (OCP, OSP, RHV). There are no Layered Products based on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 at the present time. Therefore, this CVE is not planned to be addressed on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

To mitigate this issue, it is possible to prevent the affected code from being loaded by blocklisting the openvswitch kernel module. For instructions relating to blocklisting a kernel module, please see https://access.redhat.com/solutions/41278.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: openvswitch: integer underflow leads to out-of-bounds write in reserve_sfa_size()

cwe.name: Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')

notes.text: A race condition was found in the Linux kernel's watch queue due to a missing lock in the pipe_resize_ring(). The race condition occurs when a thread uses ioctl(IOC_WATCH_QUEUE_SET_SIZE) to resize the pipe buffer and free the old pipe buffer, while another thread uses keyctl() to trigger a notification in the watch queue, calling post_one_notification() and accessing the freed pipe buffer. This flaw allows a local user to crash the system or escalate their privileges on the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: watch queue race condition can lead to privilege escalation
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, 7 and 8 are not affected by this issue as they did not include support for general notification queue.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: watch queue race condition can lead to privilege escalation

cwe.name: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

notes.text: A buffer overflow flaw was found in the Linux kernel nfsd (network file system) subsystem. The way a user sends RPC over TCP with excess data added at the end of the message could allow a remote user to starve the resources, causing a denial of service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: nfsd buffer overflow by RPC message over TCP with garbage data
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Affected versions of the Red Hat Enterprise Linux are 8.7 and higher, because starting from the 8.7 the affected source code introduced with the errata RHSA-2022:7683.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: nfsd buffer overflow by RPC message over TCP with garbage data
